issue.title: Support for the HPPA architecture
issue.body:
Hi.
Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
Thanks.

comment.body:
I'll confirm soon, but it seems it won't compile when choosing Linux as the OS.
It seems to be because it looks for `.build/src/linux-5.16.20/arch/hppa/Makefile` instead of `.build/src/linux-5.16.20/arch/parisc/Makefile`.

issue.title: Support for the HPPA architecture
issue.body:
Hi.
Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
Thanks.

comment.body:
A PR would help. I can handle patches too. I just haven't had a chance to
look at it yet.

On Fri, 27 Oct 2023, 4:58 am danglin44, ***@***.***> wrote:

> Do I need to setup a pull request to have hppa added?
>
> Note crosstools-ng builds fine on debian-hppa.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/issues/2050#issuecomment-1781408192>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AABGAE7USAL2KIKGAZK74E3YBKCEBAVCNFSM6AAAAAA6LJ4XQWVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMYTOOBRGQYDQMJZGI>
> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

issue.title: Support for the HPPA architecture
issue.body:
Hi.
Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
Thanks.

comment.body:
I just tried your patch.
I don't know if I did something wrong, but I cannot seem to choose glibc as the C library.
Is this supported by this patch?
Thanks a lot for working on this!

issue.title: How to fix this error with ct-ng 1.25.0?

issue.title: Question on developing patches
issue.body:
Not an issues, but a question since I didn't see explicit guidance around this.

While trying to get the Ada Canadian Cross (Linux to windows to m68k bare metal)  to compile I ran into a few issues with Ada source in GCC 10.5.0.
I pulled in specific line changes from a handful of files in GCC 11.4.0, but not necessarily a wholesale commit to diff between. 
I made a patch file, stuffed it in with the rest of the 10.5.0 patches and all was successfully applied (for me) and the build no longer errors out.

Is this a kind of patch you would want comitted? 

I can only really test it on the few configurations I'm building, which are all Canadian Crosses.

issue.title: Add gnatls
issue.body:
Fix for  issue #2048

crosstool-NG.sh
Add gnatls to the list of tools pulled into the build environment. This is needed just like gnatbind and gnatmake for Ada.
Added comment in area check for tools to see if someone would want to check the required tools based on additional languages selected 

Updated comment in TODO to add gnatls to list

comment.body:
Ok. I think I got that in.
With that being said I think gnatlink also needs to be added to the list of tools to copy over, so if you want to hold off on merging I'll be testing a change to add gnatlink as well. I'll try to squash/sign and push with the existing change. If something I have done at this point is causing problem with the workflow let me know and I'll address it.

issue.title: path.sh not generated correctly under MSYS2
issue.body:
- crosstools-ng 1.26.0 or cf6b174
- OS Win 11 22H22
- "MSYS2 MSYS" prompt from msys2

paths.sh has no path for python and causes an error during build (missing /usr/bin). Manually adding it allows the build to continue.

contents of path.sh

export install="/usr/bin/install -c"
export bash="/usr/bin/bash"
export bison="/usr/bin/bison"
export awk="/usr/bin/gawk"
export grep="/usr/bin/grep"
export gmake="/usr/bin/make"
export gnumake="/usr/bin/make"
export make="/usr/bin/make"
export python="python3.11"
export sed="/usr/bin/sed"
export libtool="/usr/bin/libtool"
export libtoolize="/usr/bin/libtoolize"
export objcopy="/usr/bin/objcopy"
export objdump="/usr/bin/objdump"
export readelf="/usr/bin/readelf"
export patch="/usr/bin/patch"
export md5sum="/usr/bin/md5sum"
export sha1sum="/usr/bin/sha1sum"
export sha256sum="/usr/bin/sha256sum"
export sha512sum="/usr/bin/sha512sum"

comment.body:
Yes. If I edit 

export python="python3.11"

to be 

export python="/usr/bin/python3.11"

life is good. 

Also I can see in the configure log it finds it correctly at that path, but the variable use to populate path.sh does not contain the path.

Added comment in area check for tools to see if someone would want to check the required tools based on additional languages selected 

Updated comment in TODO to add gnatls to list

comment.body:
> Looks like I can't sign through github desktop so I'll get the command line stuff installed and try that way

Signed-off-by is just some text that you can add manualy

issue.title: Support for the HPPA architecture
issue.body:
Hi.
Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
Thanks.

comment.body:
That's not really how open source software works. If hppa is your
particular itch then feel free to scratch it. Changes adding hppa would be
welcome.

The good news is hppa seems to be supported by binutils, glibc and gcc. So
adding should be quite doable.

The most recent architecture added was loongarch in
https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/commit/e840986fa if your
looking for something to refer to. There's also
https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/pull/1558 from the last drive
by request.

On Mon, 23 Oct 2023, 2:24 pm antoyo, ***@***.***> wrote:

> Hi.
> Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
> Thanks.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/issues/2050>, or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AABGAE24MF4JRGHZPKFTU73YAXBOPAVCNFSM6AAAAAA6LJ4XQWVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43ASLTON2WKOZRHE2TMMJXGIYTQOI>
> .

>

issue.title: Support for the HPPA architecture
issue.body:
Hi.
Could you please add support for the HPPA architecture?
Thanks.

issue.title: Ada language support
issue.body:
Thanks for producing such an intuitive tool.
I was just curious regarding the current status of Ada support. From looking through the source it looks like there's some minimal support when experimental features are enabled. What degree of success can be expected producing cross compilers with Ada support? I'm currently doing research into producing viable GNAT cross-compilers, and should I have any real success, if there's anything of value I can contribute I'd be glad to. If crosstool-ng can already solve this issue for me that would be even better.
Thanks again.

comment.body:
I've spent tons of time to get it works.

[Here](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:ila.embsys:zephyr-ada/zephyr-crosstool-ng) is packaged crosstool-ng with patches that enable Ada lang.
[Here](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:ila.embsys:zephyr-ada/zephyr-sdk-ada) is compiled and packaged toolchain with Ada 

The demo is available [here](https://github.com/zephyr-ada/ada-project-example).

And it still unusable because Ada's RTS doesn't exist for Zephyr.

The root problem of writing an RTS is Ada/C bindings for Zephyr's codebase. Zephyr is configurable by C macros that break the bindings. This problem is described in the presentation '[Using Zephyr with Non-C Languages](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4cZK6ceNMX0)'.


The bindings could be generated by Ada's compiler, but the generated code doesn't cover all Zephyr's functions.

issue.title: Add gnatls
issue.body:
Fix for  issue #2048

crosstool-NG.sh
Add gnatls to the list of tools pulled into the build environment. This is needed just like gnatbind and gnatmake for Ada.
Added comment in area check for tools to see if someone would want to check the required tools based on additional languages selected 

Updated comment in TODO to add gnatls to list

Command line wise `git commit -s` will add a Signed-off-by line when
creating a commit. `git rebase --interactive` is a handy way of rearranging
commits or squashing them together.
